node.title: Michael never told anyone about the thoughts in his head until they landed him in prison
node.description: All Michael wanted as a kid was for the bad thoughts to go away. And one day they did, but the reason why led him down a dark path.
node.content:
["At a small plastic desk in a room identical to the one next door, Michael Raydan wrote a birthday message to his dad for his 56th birthday.", "But he couldn't make the pen move. Was Dad really 56?", "His fingers counted up the years \u2026 and he found himself reaching 57, 58, 59\u00a0\u2026 as memories flooded his vision.", "Wasn't Dad actually 61? Had he missed his 60th? How old was his nephew now? How old was he?", "It was like being out at sea, Michael says, shrouded in a\u00a0drug-fuelled haze.", "Now the haze was lifting and the reality of a life chasing highs came rushing into his cell.", "He had to make a choice: die\u00a0right now\u00a0in this hell. Or get up\u00a0and try again.", "He chose to try.\u00a0And he had three years to figure it out.", "
Sick in the head, and no-one could know\u00a0
", "", "
Michael grew up with loving parents in Melbourne's inner south-east.(Supplied)
", "Before prison, before the courts, the drugs and the ruined relationships, Michael's life was amazingly normal.", "He grew up in Melbourne's south-east with his mum\u00a0Jo, who worked in sales, and dad\u00a0Frank, who worked in insurance. He played basketball three nights a week and says he had what it took to go pro.", "Michael watched The Simpsons every night with his brothers, he looked forward to traditional Lebanese dinners at his grandparents' house; buttery scrambled eggs doused in cumin with toasted flatbread.", "But he also had visions.", "Starting around eight or nine years old, horror movie scenes reeled across his mind, where his parents and brothers were murdered or hit by cars.", "\"It was a daily dialogue of death and doom,\" Michael says.", "He would make up excuses to go home from a friend's\u00a0house, lie to teachers so he could call his mum to make sure she was safe. Shame barred him from telling anyone about the chaos inside his head.", "", "
Michael was bullied as a child and turned to violence to cope.(Supplied)
", "Michael told himself he was sick in the head, and no-one could know.", "As he grew older, the visions grew stronger, morphing into psychosis and panic attacks.", "At 12, he discovered strategies to cope.\u00a0He lashed out at school \u2014 asking for a fight \u2014\u00a0because when he was fighting,\u00a0he wasn't feeling anxious. It was his first high.", "In a toilet block at Sandringham High School four\u00a0years later,\u00a0he found his second.", "He'd been offered speed before, he says, but this time something about the white smoke the older kid was puffing out piqued his interest. As he inhaled, his fear died.", "", "
Michael was a talented student and received a scholarship to Brighton Grammar. \u00a0(Supplied)
", "For the first time, he wanted to talk to people, he wanted to be social.", "The occasional snort of uppers descended into a daily habit; the guys he went to for a hit offered him harder elixirs.", "His parents put him in $748-a-night rehab centres three times, where he was introduced to benzodiazepines, like Valium and Xanax. He says he mastered the art of manipulating doctors into prescribing months' worth of the stuff once he was out.", "By the time he was in year 12,\u00a0Michael says he was a \"raging drug addict\".", "After high school, it just got worse.\u00a0He brought gun-wielding men to the house and\u00a0introduced them to his younger brothers.", "Then, on July 30, 2016, high on ice and cocaine, and armed, he was involved in a break-in and a man was shot.", "Michael went home, told his parents what had happened, and called the police. He was arrested, charged, and sentenced to three-and-a-half years in jail.", "He never pulled the trigger but the judge remarked his involvement was \"very serious\" and that it would take a \"considerable period\" for the victims to gain closure.", "He was 27.", "
Navigating life on the inside
", "The years passed slowly.", "Michael\u00a0learnt it was better to always be busting for the toilet than risk not being able to perform during a urine test, something that could lead to 24-hours in \"the slot\" \u2013 an empty room with no windows and nothing to do.", "He learnt which guards were there for the right reasons, he says, and which ones were there just to make your life hell. He learnt where it was safe to break down.", "He watched men clutch the ankles of guards and beg to remain rather than be released, and he saw men leave only to turn on their heels a few months later and walk back in.", "", "
Michael carries many difficult lessons learnt during his time behind bars.(ABC News: Jean Edwards)
", "He is\u00a0under no illusion that prison is unnecessary.", "\"Break the law and your liberties are taken away from you,\" he says.", "But Michael\u00a0takes issue with how people are treated once those liberties are given back.", "He saw men spend years in isolation before being released to a world that treated them with unforgiving suspicion.", "They were denied work and a place to live, many couldn't find friends who weren't drug addicts or gun peddlers.", "As the years inside dwindled to months, Michael grew afraid.", "\"It was my first time in prison, and I had no idea what it would be like when I left,\" he says.", "Luckily, he was about to meet someone who did.", "", "
Michael credits meeting Joe with keeping him on track after prison.(ABC News: Rachel Clayton)
", "
Defying prison's return rate
", "Joe is a six-foot straight-talker who is the epitome of proving\u00a0incarceration doesn't have to define someone's life.", "He landed himself in prison 13 times through fraud, burglaries, and stealing wallets out of trolleys.", "For 30 years, Joe perfected the pirouette; spinning in and out of cuffs and courtrooms.", "", "
Joe Ranieri now helps\u00a0men in boarding houses with\u00a0their health and wellbeing.\u00a0(ABC News: Rachel Clayton)
", "For Joe and countless others, reoffending, rearrest, and being sent back to prison\u00a0are often the only options they can see when they're freed.", "More than 44 per cent of people released from prison in Victoria return within two years, according to the Sentencing Council. The rate across the nation is more than 46 per cent.", "And while states like Texas in the United States are closing prisons and reducing the number of prisoners, Victoria is building a new one to fit more people in.", "The number of prisoners in the Victorian system by July 2020 had increased almost 58 per cent compared to a decade earlier, and was costing taxpayers $323.45 per day, per prisoner.", "So, two years ago, a researcher from Geelong's Deakin University decided to try something new: a mentoring\u00a0program.", "Men who had left prison and were doing well were recruited to return, this time through the front door, to support those whose sentences were coming to an end.", "", "
Joe hopes to take part in the mentoring\u00a0program again to help men leaving prison from returning.(ABC News: Rachel Clayton)
", "Michael was lucky to have his family by his side when he was released, but he says without Joe he would have been lost.", "It was difficult for his family to understand and they grew tired of him talking about prison, which at times was all Michael wanted to do.", "Joe was the constant he needed in his life. He didn't judge and never gave unsolicited advice or opinions.", "When Michael wanted to find people from his past to rekindle relationships, Joe warned him to stay away.", "But it has\u00a0not been an easy path back.", "", "
Michael fears how his boss will react when they find out about his past.(ABC News: Rachel Clayton\u00a0)
", "The stigma of disclosing a prison record is something Michael experienced firsthand.", "When he was offered a promotion and wanted to tell his boss about prison, Joe told him it wasn't worth it. He did anyway and was fired the next day.", "According to the Australian Humans Rights Commission, a person does not have to disclose their criminal record to an employer, unless they are legally required to, such as if they are\u00a0applying for a job to work with children.", "And employers must ask for consent to conduct a police check.", "After a lifetime of lying, Michael says\u00a0all he has left is the truth.", "
Battling 'gate fever'
", "Just one person involved in Deakin's\u00a014-person mentoring\u00a0program was sent back to prison, lead researcher Joseph Graffam says.", "\"That person was incarcerated because of a breach in his parole conditions \u2014 wrong place, wrong time. He was in a mall and bumped into a family member he was not allowed to be in contact with,\" he says.", "\"But no-one reoffended.\"", "It's an impressive result, Professor Graffam says.", "One effective tactic of the mentoring\u00a0was making sure the mentor was at the gate when their mentee was released.", "\"A lot of people who leave prison reoffend between the gate and the city,\" Professor Graffam says.", "\"People are very anxious when they leave prison \u2014 it's called gate fever.\"", "Professor Graffam co-wrote a report on the 18-month program, but the pandemic sidelined almost everything that wasn't related to coronavirus and he hasn't heard anything from the Department of Justice\u00a0in two years.", "He says this is\u00a0despite\u00a0initial support from the department to roll out the program across other prisons.", "A Department of Justice\u00a0spokesperson said the government delivered\u00a0rehabilitation and reintegration programs to help break the cycle of reoffending in partnership with community and educational organisations.", "They\u00a0did not comment on the Deakin program.\u00a0", "
Who are you to the world after prison?
", "Michael\u00a0turns from the slip lane down a short drive, backs\u00a0his car towards the gate, and heads\u00a0into work, his heart fluttering.", "It's today. Today's the day, he thought. They know about my past. Someone told them, or they Googled, or perhaps they've always known and this is the day they speak up.", "He edges open the double chain-link fence, spots his boss and smiles.", "They exchange polite greetings; he's well, she's fine. He starts placing crimson bouquets wrapped in crisp smooth paper into his boot that's lined with plastic water containers.", "Lilies, gerberas, posies hugged in hessian, a fruit basket for a woman who lost her husband, boxes of chocolates from a\u00a0boss for his staff.", "He clicks shut the boot and releases his breath. The first address is loaded onto his GPS, the car rolls towards the highway.", "He'll tell them eventually, he thinks, just maybe not today."]
